comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
This is a pseudo stereo pair.
A single camera has been used on a tripod, but the photographer has not moved the camera sideways between exposures.
Some chimney shadows have moved between exposures.

You can take stereos with any single camera, providing the subject is not moving.
If you rig up 2 identical cameras side-by-side you can take stereos of moving objects.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] "Pseudo"? I'm affronted and appalled!  :)

Have you had a look at any of the others in the Twice as Nice set? Are they too pseudos?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Ross Castle is a genuine stereo using 2 cameras side-by-side. www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/5929025491/in/set-7215762... The boat figures leap into the foreground. The one of the Barque in Cork City is not genuine stereo. Demand your money back. www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6142795107/in/set-7215762...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Here it is in animated 3D. Even with a stereoviewer the effect if very subtle as there are no foreground objects.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] in your first comment you've said "the photographer has not moved the camera sideways between exposures". Surely he *has* moved it, hence simulating the effect of a twin lensed stereo camera?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Excellent work wiggling the images. I should have said "the photographer has not moved the camera enough sideways between exposures". I did this type of shot 40 years ago from the top of a church tower in Cambridge. With nothing in the foreground you can move the camera 12 inches or more.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] thanks. I also tried it out but more recently, including a couple in Lacock where Fox Talbot lived - see www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture/sets/7215762636565.... Digital is certainly a lot easier than wet plate collodion!
